parameter 1: As with Supercop, the US distributor, Buena Vista, decided to cut the film for its domestic release. Approximately 8 minutes of footage were removed. Additionaly the original score was replaced with a new one by Michael Wandmacher.
parameter 2: DVD deleted and extended scenes: - Interview with potential employee Gordon Pinella. - A scene featuring Doyle's supervisor telling him he needs to "make a change" or he was going to be fired. - Extended confession scene in which Gavin verbally admits to his affair and tells the priest that God is a joke.
parameter 3: Early video versions featured the 87 min documentary. Later releases included "Dinner With The Champions" which boosted the running time to 115 mins.
parameter 4: DVD deleted and extended scenes: - Interview with potential employee Gordon Pinella. - A scene featuring Doyle's supervisor telling him he needs to "make a change" or he was going to be fired. - Extended confession scene in which Gavin verbally admits to his affair and tells the priest that God is a joke.
parameter 5: Early video versions featured the 87 min documentary. Later releases included "Dinner With The Champions" which boosted the running time to 115 mins.
parameter 6: The UK version cuts out the scene where Paula strangled a forewoman in bed. The scene faded to black right after she put her hands around her neck and right after that the forewoman is shown dead.  The strangling scene is shown uncut in the video version available in Asia and shown on US cable.
parameter 7: The 1986 and 1990 UK video versions were cut by 1 min 38 secs by the BBFC to remove the rape before the fight on the roof and to heavily edit fight scenes including groin kicks, face slaps and a woman's head being hit against a window. Some fight cuts were restored in the 1998 MIA video release though most of the original BBFC edits were retained. The 2006 Anchor Bay DVD had been heavily pre-edited and was missing the BBFC cuts along with some other edits.
parameter 8: ABC edited 20 minutes from this film for its 1987 network television premiere.
parameter 9: Produced as a TV series pilot, this film was determined to be too violent for the small screen and given theatrical distribution instead. Added for this release was an exploitation device called the "Fear Flasher/Horror Horn", ostensibly to warn the audience of the "Four Supreme Fright Points" (although it was not applied to the picture's most explicitly violent moment, the climactic fate of the villain). This device was explained in an introductory sequence narrated by _'William Conrad (I)'_(qv). Upon first showing on US network television, both the device and its explanation were deleted, but in subsequent syndication to local stations in the 1970s and '80s, some such prints were seen.
parameter 10: Rereleased in edited form with all sex scenes removed.
parameter 11: The 2004 US R-rated video release also removed the strangulation scene.
parameter 12: The Japanese video/DVD release is uncut by all lower frontal nudity is fuzzed out.
parameter 13: As with Supercop, the US distributor, Buena Vista, decided to cut the film for its domestic release. Approximately 8 minutes of footage were removed. Additionaly the original score was replaced with a new one by Michael Wandmacher.
parameter 14: To receive a 12 certificate the original UK cinema version was cut to remove one use of 'fucking' (during Charlie's homecoming visit to a pub). Later releases were uncut and upgraded to a 15 rating.
parameter 15: Rereleased in edited form with all sex scenes removed.
parameter 16: To receive a 12 certificate the original UK cinema version was cut to remove one use of 'fucking' (during Charlie's homecoming visit to a pub). Later releases were uncut and upgraded to a 15 rating.

parameter 19: The UK Warner video was cut by 1 min 53 secs with edits to a scene where a man caresses Maya and slashes her clothes with a knife.

parameter 22: The UK Warner video was cut by 1 min 53 secs with edits to a scene where a man caresses Maya and slashes her clothes with a knife.
parameter 23: In 2008 a first short Version of 49 Minutes "Der Traum vom Fussball Star" (The Dream of becoming a Soccer Star) was released bei Swiss TV SF. In 2009 the Theatrical and DVD Version of 67 Min. "Champions von Morgen" (Champions of tomorrow) was released, but also broad casted by Swiss TV SF.
parameter 24: The only uncut video version available in North America is the French language dubbed version titled "Femmes enchaînées: Q.H.S. 3" distributed in the province of Quebec, Canada.
parameter 25: When first released, Hepburn's line "at any moment we could be assassinated" was dubbed over to become "at any moment we could be eliminated" due to the Kennedy assassination. Subsequent releases have "assassinated" restored to its place in the film.
parameter 26: The original cut had a voice-over narration by April Monique Burril for some of the scenes including the opening scene.
parameter 27: There was an early review of the movie that contained a spoiler of the ending. The ending that was originally used involved 'Ben Affleck' (qv) and 'Samuel L. Jackson' (qv) getting into a fist fight that leads onto the balcony. They talk about right and wrong and Affleck takes the file and tears it up and the movie fades to credits. This ending was most likely cut because test audiences did not like it. It will most likely appear on the DVD. Also a small clip shown in the TV ads shows Affleck and Jackson fighting on the balcony. This was part of the original ending which explains why it was cut.
parameter 28: The 2004 US R-rated video release also removed the strangulation scene.
parameter 29: Milestone Film and Video has issued a video with a music score by Bruce Gaston (copyrighted in 1991) and performed by Fong Naam.  The running time is 69 minutes.
parameter 30: As with Supercop, the US distributor, Buena Vista, decided to cut the film for its domestic release. Approximately 8 minutes of footage were removed. Additionaly the original score was replaced with a new one by Michael Wandmacher.
